instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
Hi guys.

I have this board which has 2 type c ports of which only one the second port works ad charges normal. This happened after using a dongle and i noticed some sticky thing on the board which i cleaning as much as possible. Any advice? 

Thanks

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
The other port stuck on 5V input?
Probably bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.
Compare diode mode readings on power rails of both chips.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message: How do the ports look are they clean? If so, I'm with 2informaticos.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
On F3000 i get 20v and on F3010 i only have 5v...

Also <CAPACITOR>C6424</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6404</CAPACITOR> are shorted on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SPKRL</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
Lot of caps connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Did you remove these two and find them shorted out of board?
Post exact resistance to ground (ohm mode) at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all big coils.

Also seems to have problem with <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, or its area.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
I asked about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; diode mode, not ohm scale.
If is really low value, or short; then use ohm scale.

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
48.8 ohms on L7430 ... and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SPKRL</SIGNAL> also a lot of caps touching the ground :D

Also when plugged in on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> on F3000 i have 30V and on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> 6.8v

threads.title: Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-01
threads.message:
"48.8 ohms on L7430"
I repeat
"I asked about <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; diode mode"

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SPKRL</SIGNAL> also a lot of caps touching the ground"
You have a fix with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SPKRL</SIGNAL>.
Did you remove <RESISTOR>R6499</RESISTOR> to be so sure is only there???
This is the reason for pending measurment asked above.

"on <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> on F3000 i have 30V and on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> 6.8v"
Change the battery of your multimeter and check again voltages.
